holidays.name: Apple Pie Day
holidays.description: A day to celebrate the classic, comforting dessert‚Äîapple pie! Whether topped with ice cream or enjoyed warm, it honors this all-American favorite.
holidays.origin: Apple Pie Day is an unofficial holiday created by pie lovers and food enthusiasts to honor the iconic dessert, which traces roots back to England and has become a symbol of American culture.
holidays.funFact: Despite the saying 'as American as apple pie,' the dish actually dates back to medieval England and was introduced to America by early colonists.

holidays.name: National Croutons Day

holidays.origin: This quirky food holiday was started by salad dressing companies to boost the popularity of croutons and encourage people to jazz up their salads.
holidays.funFact: The word 'crouton' comes from the French 'cro√ªton,' meaning 'little crust,' and croutons were originally made to use up leftover bread.

holidays.name: Leprechaun Day
holidays.description: A fun day to celebrate the mischievous little fairies of Irish folklore, known for their pots of gold and playful tricks.
holidays.origin: This unofficial day emerged from pop culture fascination with leprechauns and Irish mythology, often embraced in schools and communities to teach folklore.
holidays.funFact: Leprechauns are considered shoemakers of the fairy world and are said to hide their treasure at the end of a rainbow!

holidays.name: Frog Jumping Day
holidays.description: Inspired by the classic Mark Twain story, this day encourages folks to host or watch frog-jumping contests and celebrate quirky rural traditions.
holidays.origin: Based on Mark Twain‚Äôs 'The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County,' this local tradition grew into an annual event celebrated on or near May 13.
holidays.funFact: The original frog-jumping contest started in Calaveras County, California, in 1928 and has become a beloved yearly festival.
